    Function, Therapeutic Potential, and Inhibition of Hsp70 Chaperones

    • Andrew J. Ambrose
      Andrew J. Ambrose
      Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology, College of Pharmacy, University of Arizona, 1703 East Mabel Street, Tucson, Arizona 85721, United States
      More by Andrew J. Ambrose
      View Biography
      https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2932-4514
      • Â andÂ 
    • Eli Chapman*
      Eli Chapman
      Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology, College of Pharmacy, University of Arizona, 1703 East Mabel Street, Tucson, Arizona 85721, United States
      *[emailÂ protected]
      More by Eli Chapman
      View Biography
      https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6310-1664
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2021, 64, 11, 7060â7082

    Get e-Alerts
    SUBJECTS:
    • Cancer,

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Hsp70s are among the most highly conserved proteins in all of biology. Through an iterative binding and release of exposed hydrophobic residues on client proteins, Hsp70s can prevent aggregation and promote folding to the native state of their client proteins. The human proteome contains eight canonical Hsp70s. Because Hsp70s are relatively promiscuous they play a role in folding a large proportion of the proteome. Hsp70s are implicated in disease through their ability to regulate protein homeostasis. In recent years, researchers have attempted to develop selective inhibitors of Hsp70 isoforms to better understand the role of individual isoforms in biology and as potential therapeutics. Selective inhibitors have come from rational design, forced localization, and serendipity, but the development of completely selective inhibitors remains elusive. In the present review, we discuss the Hsp70 structure and function, the known Hsp70 client proteins, the role of Hsp70s in disease, and current efforts to discover Hsp70 modulators.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The proper folding of proteins into their correct three-dimensional and functional form is essential for the survival of every organism. In a series of landmark experiments, Anfinsen showed that all of the information needed for proper folding was contained in the primary sequence of bovine pancreatic ribonuclease and that even when trapped in off-target folding states, ribonuclease would ultimately equilibrate to its correct, functional three-dimensional structure.(1,2) This remarkable observation led to the development of the thermodynamic hypothesis: âthe native conformation is determined by the totality of interatomic interactions and hence by the amino acid sequence, in a given environmentâ.(3) However, it was already noticed by Anfinsen that there was a kinetic conundrum: proteins fold at a rate that is much too slow to support life. Heat-shock proteins were first identified in 1962 by Ritossa when a malfunctioning incubator lead to the observation of chromosomal âpuffsâ and a corresponding protein that is upregulated in drosophila in response to cellular stressors.(4) A gargantuan effort spanning decades eventually showed that these 70 kDa heat-shock proteins are highly conserved and found in all kingdoms of life.(5â7) Although no one knew it at the time of their discovery, these 70 kDa and other heat-shock proteins would eventually be shown to be the solution to Anfinsenâs kinetic protein-folding conundrum.
    Molecular chaperones are enzymes whose function is to stabilize, fold, and unfold other proteins. This term first appears in the literature in 1978 when Laskey described the role of nucleoplasmin (a molecular chaperone) in the in vitro assembly of nucleosomes, the building blocks of a chromatin structure.(8) Additionally, Laskey et al. showed that nucleoplasmin was not a member of the assembled nucleosome and that the nucleosome could be assembled independently of nucleoplasmin at specific salt concentrations. From this, it was concluded that nucleoplasmin was preventing histone aggregation by blocking spurious interactions between highly charged sites on the histones.(8) Shortly after this discovery, it was hypothesized that the stress-inducible heat-shock proteins, including the 70 kDa heat-shock protein (Hsp70), function as molecular chaperones within cells.(9)
    Although generally charged with the task of maintaining proteome integrity, the various chaperone families have distinct biophysical mechanisms and can operate in an adenosine triphosphate (ATP)-dependent or -independent manner. Organisms across all kingdoms of life express chaperones from different families that function in a carefully ordered and interconnected manner.(10) One particularly interesting chaperone family, and the focus of the present review, are the Hsp70s. Hsp70 and its cofactors are particularly well-characterized on the molecular level due to decades of careful research. Over the last 30 years the Hsp70s have drawn attention as therapeutic targets due to their roles in protein folding and their overexpression in cancer. While several inhibitors of these proteins have been described, none have yet advanced to the clinic. The Hsp70s are highly conserved and are expressed in all organisms, but the number of these proteins that organisms express differs between kingdoms. For example, bacteria express one predominant Hsp70 with two other Hsp70 isoforms expressed at trace levels, while eukaryotes from yeast to humans express eight canonical Hsp70 isoforms that differ in tissue specificity, inducibility, and subcellular locale. Despite their critical biological function and disease relevance, not much is known about the function of specific Hsp70 isoforms. This is likely attributable to the lack of chemical and biological tools to dissect the isoform function. In this review we will describe the general structure and function of Hsp70s, the role of Hsp70s in disease, what is known about the individual isoforms, and progress toward the development of specific probes and therapeutics targeting these proteins in humans.

    2. The Hsp70 Machine

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    2.1. Domain Architecture of Hsp70

    Hsp70 proteins are among the most highly conserved chaperones and are ubiquitous throughout living organisms.(5) These proteins are made of an â¼35 kDa N-terminal nucleotide binding domain (NBD) and an â¼25 kDa C-terminal substrate binding domain (SBD) (Figure 1A).(11â13) Each of these domains can be further divided into subdomains. The SBD is subdivided into a Î²-sheet-rich base and an Î±-helix-rich lid, which function together as a clamp when presented with substrate polypeptide sequences (Figure 1A). The NBD is composed of four lobes arranged in pairs; referred to as IA, IB, IIA, and IIB (Figure 1B). The ATP binding site is positioned in such a manner that it can coordinate and control all four subdomains in the NBD (Figure 1C). The ATP bound state (Figure 1C) is the open, low client protein affinity state. When ATP is hydrolyzed the lid closes over the SBD, creating the high affinity state (Figure 1D). Outside of the domains, there is a disordered linker connecting the NBD and SBD, which is essential for allosteric communication and a disordered tail that, in higher organisms, contains an EEVD (Glutamic acid-Glutamic acid-Valine-Aspartic acid) motif that plays an essential role in the C-terminus of Hsc70-interacting protein (CHIP) and Hsp90 organizing protein (HOP) binding (Figure 1A).(11â16) This EEVD motif is only present on the cytoplasmic Hsp70 isoforms, as only they interact with CHIP and Hsp90.

    2.2. Hsp70 Holding Cycle

    Hsp70 proteins perform their cellular functions through a cycle of clamping and unclamping in the SBD (Figure 1C,D). To accomplish this, they rely on two cochaperones, namely, a J-domain containing protein (JDP) and a nucleotide exchange factor (NEF). JDPs fall into three groups, class A, B, and C, that differ based on their structural organization. Class A and B JDPs have their J-domain at the N-terminus, while in class C J-domain proteins the J-domain can be anywhere in their structure. Class A JDPs have a rigid organization of the J-domain, glycine/phenylalanine-rich linker (G/F-linker), a zinc-binding Î²-barrel domain, a second Î²-barrel domain, and a dimerization domain at the C-terminus. Class B JDPs comprise all other JDPs that contain an N-terminal J domain followed by a G/F-linker.(17) The J-domain of JDPs interacts with Hsp70, and other domains in the JDP associate with exposed hydrophobic polypeptides on client proteins (Figure 2, steps 1 and 2). Thus, one hypothesized function of JDP is to bring client proteins to Hsp70.(18) JDP can stimulate the ATPase activity of Hsp70s, so once a client peptide is brought to an ATP-bound Hsp70 by a JDP, the ATP is hydrolyzed, and the Hsp70 SBD clamps onto the polypeptide (Figure 2, step 3). The conformational change of clamping triggers the release of the JDP cochaperone. Next, a nucleotide exchange factor releases adenosine diphosphate (ADP) from the NBD (Figure 2, step 4) replacing it with ATP (Figure 2, step 5). At this point the client protein is released, and the cycle can begin again (Figure 2, step 6).(13,19,20)
    At first glance, it is not clear why this iterative cycle of binding and release can contribute to a protein reaching its correctly folded (native) state. The peptides that bind to the SBD of Hsp70 tend to consist of seven amino acids with the central four or five being hydrophobic and the flanking amino acids bearing a positive formal charge at physiologic pH.(21â24) Sequences of this nature are common in proteins throughout the kingdoms of life, but they are almost exclusively found buried deep within proteins.(10) These sequences can be prone to aggregation if they are exposed in a solvent such as during an initial translation or a heat stress. Hsp70 can be thought of as protecting these hydrophobic sequences through timed binding and release, diminishing unfavorable intermolecular interactions and giving a client protein time to reach its native state.(25)

    2.3. Allosteric Communication within Hsp70

    To effectively prevent aggregation and promote folding of client proteins, Hsp70 enzymes require these non-native clients to bind rapidly and to stay bound for a relatively long time.(11,12) This kinetic profile is achieved through the clamping action of the lid and base of the SBD, which is regulated by the ATP state of the NBD. When ATP is bound, the opposing lobes of the NBD are brought together, prying the lid of the SBD into an open state (Figure 1C). Once ATP is hydrolyzed to ADP, the NBD lobes relax apart, and the lid returns to its closed state (Figure 1D). While in the open conformation, substrate proteins have a relatively low affinity for the SBD with an on rate of â¼106 Mâ1 sâ1 and an off rate of â¼1 sâ1. Once the lid closes, the affinity for substrate is â¼10-fold higher driven by an â¼1000-fold decrease in the off rate and â¼100-fold decrease in the on rate.
    In addition to allosteric regulation of the SBD by the NBD, there is also regulation of the NBD by the SBD. When DnaK is in the ATP bound open conformation, the base of the SBD pushes some of the catalytic ATPase residues out of their optimal position, resulting in a suboptimal rate of ATP hydrolysis.(12,26) Binding of a substrate to the SBD moves the base of the SBD away from the NBD, resulting in a moderate ATPase stimulation and allowing the four lobes of the NBD to relax again, resulting in a suboptimal rate of ATP hydrolysis. Therefore, DnaK is only able to achieve its maximal rate of ATP hydrolysis in the presence of both a substrate peptide and a JDP cofactor. In the specific case of Escherichia coli Hsp70 (DnaK), the presence of a substrate peptide and JDP cofactor (DnaJ) can increase the rate of ATP hydrolysis up to 15â¯000-fold and can increase the substrate affinity by â¼100-fold.(11â13) Of note, the stimulation of the Hsp70 ATPase activity by a substrate peptide is not ubiquitous. It has been shown that the stimulation of ATPase activity by HspA1A, HspA8, and DnaK by a substrate peptide is unequal.(27) In this work, the authors identify a series of residues at the NBD-SBD interface of these Hsp70s that lower the affinity between HspA8 and HspA1A and the substrate peptide. Because of this lower affinity, HspA8 is less frequently in complex with both the peptide substrate and ATP, and HspA1A is even less frequently in this ternary complex. This causes HspA1 and HspA8 to lose the ability of their ATPase activity to be increased by the substrate peptides.

    3. Hsp70 Substrates

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The first structure of the SBD of an Hsp70 was solved in a conformation with the model peptide NRLLLTG.(24) This structure revealed that the peptide binds along a hydrophobic cleft at the interface of the lid and the base of the SBD (Figure 3). Within this cleft, the central leucine of the model peptide appears to be the only side chain deeply buried in a pocket found at the base of the SBD (Figure 3). Since the publication of this first structure, structures of related Hsp70s have been reported bound to this peptide.(28) While it is not always the central leucine bound in the deep pocket, it is always only one amino acidâs side chain that appears to be buried (Figure 3C). Because only one amino acid is deeply buried, much of the binding energy is likely derived from an interaction with the peptide backbone. Since peptide backbones are identical regardless of the sequence, Hsp70s can bind many disparate peptide sequences found in various client proteins. Studies of minimal substrate binding to Hsp70s reveal that, in general, the SBD favors peptides that consist of seven amino acids with a hydrophobic middle three to five residues flanked by charged (usually basic) amino acids.(29) Machine learning has been used to develop a prediction algorithm for peptides interacting with DnaK.(23) This algorithm, which is based on molecular modeling and evidence of binding, shows that the hydrophobic core of interacting peptides contributes more to affinity than the flanking residues and that the core three amino acids are less tolerant of variability than the flanking residues. While some studies have investigated peptide binding differences between Hsp70 isoforms, there has yet to be a systematic comparison of peptide association with different Hsp70 family members. In general, it is thought that Hsp70 clients are determined by JDP cochaperone interactions (Figure 2, step 1).(18)

    4. Hsp70 Functions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Through an iterative binding and release of non-native polypeptides Hsp70 can perform a vast array of functions that are dependent on a series of other cochaperones. In Eukarya, a protein referred to as the Hsp70â90 organizing protein (HOP) is capable of recruiting Hsp90 to the Hsp70-ADP-substrate complex. At this point, the substrate can be transferred from Hsp70 to Hsp90, which acts to further promote the folding of the substrate.(15) A second cochaperone, CHIP, binds to the same EEVD motif as HOP and functions as an E3 ubiquitin ligase promoting degradation of the substrate protein. Because CHIP competes with HOP for binding, substrates that spend longer periods of time associated with Hsp70 are more likely to be ubiquitylated and degraded. CHIP and HOP thus function as timers, preventing substrate proteins that are not folding correctly from saturating the chaperone network.(14,16)
    In the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), the communication between folding and degradation pathways by HspA5 is regulated through an interaction with distinct sequences. HspA5 tends to interact with less aggregation-prone hydrophobic stretches, while the ER resident Hsp110, Grp170, and the JDPs ERDJ4/5 interact with more aggregation-prone sequences. It is hypothesized that these more aggregation-prone sequences act as timers. Non-native polypeptides are protected at these sites through an interaction with Grp170. If Grp170 spends too much time on this site it is replaced by ERDJ4 or 5, which signals the polypeptide to be subjected to endoplasmic reticulum-associated degradation (ERAD). However, if hydrophobic stretches are able to fold rapidly enough, they will get buried before ERDJ4/5 can access them, and the protein will proceed with folding or aggregation.(30)
    Another major function of Hsp70 in Eukarya is the trafficking of proteins to their destination organelle.(31) To be localized to the mitochondria or ER, proteins are tagged with peptide sequences on their N-termini and must be kept unfolded until they reach their target organelle. Hsp70 plays a key role in keeping these proteins unfolded until their targeting sequences are captured by the appropriate translocation machinery. Once the membrane translocation begins, Hsp70 within the destination compartment binds the entering peptides and provides an entropic force to help bring the polypeptide into the compartment.(32)
    The most widely known function of Hsp70 is to facilitate the folding of nascent polypeptides coming off the ribosome or stress-denatured polypeptides. This happens at all levels of life and is a result of Hsp70 protecting specific aggregation-prone sequences until an entire folding unit (such as a domain) is translated or refolded. This helps prevent the folding from proceeding down non-native and aggregation-prone pathways.(11)

    5. Hsp70 Isoforms in Humans

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    While Hsp70 is ubiquitous throughout life, organisms typically have multiple distinct Hsp70 proteins.(33) These Hsp70 proteins can be generally classified into canonical and noncanonical groups. Canonical Hsp70s contain all three of the typical Hsp70 structural features (NBD, SBD, and a disordered linker between the domains), while noncanonical Hsp70s contain an NBD and lack one of the other structural features. In humans there are 13 Hsp70 protein isoforms, including 8 canonical and 5 noncanonical proteins (Table 1).
    Table 1. Human Hsp70 Isoformsa
    genecanonicalEEVD motiflocalizationheat inducible
    HspA1AYesYescytoplasm/nucleusYes
    HspA1LYesYesCytoplasm/nucleusNo
    HspA2YesYescytoplasm/nucleusNo
    HspA5YesNoERYes
    HspA6YesYescytoplasm/nucleusYes
    HspA8YesYescytoplasm/nucleusNo
    HspA9YesNomitochondriaNo
    HspA7NoNoN/AN/A
    Hsp12ANoNocytoplasm/nucleusN/A
    Hsp12BNoNocytoplasm/nucleusN/A
    HspA13NoNocytoplasm/nucleusN/A
    HspA14NoNocytoplasm/nucleusN/A
    a

    N/A indicates Not Applicable.

    All eight canonical proteins have been studied in both biochemical and physiological contexts. These canonical Hsp70s can be further classified by organelle or tissue specificity as well as being inducible or constitutive. Inducible Hsp70 are those whose levels are increased upon exposure to proteostatic stress, while constitutive Hsp70s have similar expression levels under varied conditions. A stress induction of Hsp70 isoforms happens through the activity of heat-shock factor 1 (HSF1). Under basal conditions, levels of free inducible Hsp70s are extremely low, with most of these isoforms being held in a complex with Hsp90 and HSF1. When the proteome is stressed, either through a heat shock or some other means, Hsp70 and Hsp90 are competed off HSF1 by non-native proteins. Free HSF1 then travels to the nucleus and induces the expression of many heat-shock proteins including HspA1A and HspA1B (discussed in detail below). The canonical Hsp70s are highly conserved in sequence and structure (Figure 4).(34) While these proteins are highly homologous, there are three areas that are relatively less conserved. The first is the lid of the substrate binding domain (Figure 4B, blue circle). This area does not have a defined function but could play a role in binding to substrates that possess a significant tertiary structure.(35) The second region of relatively low homology is at the NEF binding interface (Figure 4B, green circle). This lends validity to the hypothesis that each Hsp70 isoform interacts with a distinct set of cochaperones. Similarly, the JDP binding site (Figure 4B, orange circle) is less highly conserved. The extensive homology among isoforms has led to the assumption that cytoplasmic isoforms are functionally redundant. However, as discussed in detail below, recent studies have called this observation into question.(36â38)

    5.1. HspA1A and A1B (Hsp70.1 and 70.2)

    HspA1A and HspA1B are the most highly conserved Hsp70s in humans, differing by only two amino acids. They represent the major cytoplasmic heat-inducible Hsp70s.(49) It would be very difficult to differentiate these two isoforms using standard techniques such as immunoblotting or quantitative polymerase chain reaction (PCR). As a result, it is challenging to assign a function to one of these isoforms independently. Researchers typically do not differentiate between these two proteins, and, as a result, they are sometimes collectively referred to as Hsp70.(50â52) As the major heat-inducible Hsp70 proteins in humans, HspA1A and HspA1B are among the most abundant proteins in the cytoplasm after proteome stress.(53) In addition, these proteins have been observed extracellularly and anchored to the cell membrane in cancer, contributing to inflammation and an immune response in tumors.(54)

    5.2. HspA1L (HspA1-t, HspA1-hom)

    Like HspA1A and A1B, HspA1L is found in the cytoplasm, but HspA1L is primarily found in the testes in men and the ovaries in women.(34,55) While not extensively studied, it is known that HspA1L is not induced by heat shock and can play a significant role in sperm development.(49) Additionally, correlation-based studies implicate HspA1L expression in several diseases including multiple sclerosis, spontaneous preterm birth, sound-induced deafness, and periodontitis.(56â59) However, a causative link between HspA1L and these disease phenotypes has yet to be established. The human protein atlas also lists HspA1L as generally overexpressed in glioma, lung cancer, head and neck cancer, stomach cancer, urothelial cancer, breast cancer, cervical cancer, ovarian cancer, melanoma, and skin cancer.(55)

    5.3. HspA2 (HspA1B, NOT Hsp72)

    A second Hsp70 isoform that is found enriched in the testes and ovaries is HspA2. HspA2 is also found in the central nervous system (CNS) under basal conditions, and this protein cannot be induced by a heat shock. Like HspA1L, HspA2 plays a key role in sperm development and remains highly expressed within mature sperm.(60) HspA2 is a clinically significant marker of sperm quality in both in vitro fertilization and general male fertility. Spermatids lacking high levels of HspA2 cannot recognize structures on the surface of eggs as a result of either improper development or maintenance of receptor proteins on the sperm.(54) The role of HspA2 in female reproductive health is not known, and no studies have looked at the relationship between female fertility and HspA2 expression. Similarly, the function of HspA2 within the brain and CNS is not known, but HspA2 is known to be involved in the progression of Alzheimerâs disease.(61,62)

    5.4. HspA5 (BIP or Grp78)

    HspA5 is the only Hsp70 protein found in the endoplasmic reticulum. Under basal conditions, HspA5 is found at low levels, where it functions to inhibit the inositol-requiring enzyme 1 (IRE1) and eukaryotic translation initiation factor 2-alpha kinase 3 (PERK) arms of the unfolded protein response (UPR). Under stressed conditions, HspA5 is competed off IRE1 and PERK allowing them to dimerize and signal the overexpression of chaperones within the ER.(63) Because of this regulation, HspA5 is inducible by heat shock, although it is not regulated by HSF-1. In addition to the regulation of the UPR, HspA5 plays a role in the folding of various ER localized proteins.(64) HspA5 is essential for the translocation of proteins into the ER. As described above, this is due to the entropic effect caused by a restricted movement of HspA5 after binding to an entering polypeptide. In the ER, protein levels are regulated through ERAD, by which unfolded or misfolded proteins are removed and targeted for a proteolytic degradation.(65) HspA5 plays an essential role in this process by solubilizing proteins that are to be retro-translocated out of the ER and tagged for degradation. Knockout of HspA5 is lethal to embryos in mice, but a heterozygous knockout yields mice that are more resistant to obesity and the onset (but not late-stage growth) of breast cancer.(66â68)

    5.5. HspA6

    HspA6, like HspA1A, is a cytoplasmic and heat-shock-inducible Hsp70 isoform. However, HspA6 does have some unique characteristics including an extra heat-shock element (HSE) that is not bound by heat-shock factors (HSF) 1 or 2, which regulate the canonical heat-shock response in mammalian cells.(69) The unique HSE is bound by an uncharacterized transcription factor in addition to HSF1 and HSF2. Another difference between HspA6 and HspA1A/B is that HspA6 is found at much lower levels under basal conditions than HspA1A/B and, as a result, HspA6 associates more slowly with clients during heat stress. Additionally, HspA6 is unable to chaperone the Huntingtin protein and luciferase while HspA1A/B act upon these substrates.(37) From an evolutionary perspective, HspA6 appears to have developed recently, as it is not found in the genomes of rodents. However, HspA6 is found in the genomes of larger mammals such as cattle and primates. Because of its absence in many models used to study disease, the role of HspA6 in neurodegeneration and cancer is less well-characterized than that of other Hsp70s.(70,71)

    5.6. HspA8 (Hsc70)

    HspA8 is constitutively expressed in the cytoplasm and is associated with essential housekeeping functions in the cell.(34) As a result, HspA8 is developmentally lethal when knocked out of mice.(72) The most well-characterized function of HspA8 is its role in chaperone-mediated autophagy (CMA). CMA is a selective degradation process by which proteins containing a KFERQ motif are transported into lysosomes by HspA8 and its cofactors. Interestingly, the KFERQ motif is not recognized by the canonical substrate binding site within HspA8 and, therefore, is not regulated by the nucleotide state of HspA8.(73) In addition to CMA, HspA8 is involved in the proteasomal degradation of substrates through an interaction with the E3 ligase CHIP.(14) The microtubule-associated protein tau is subject to both CMA and proteolytic degradation through independent interactions with HspA8. Since HspA8 binds to tau at its dimerization site it is thought that HspA8 may play a pivotal role in the prevention of tau aggregation.(36,74) This phenomenon of prevention of the tau aggregation will be discussed later in this review.

    5.7. HspA9 (Grp75 or Mortalin)

    HspA9 is expressed within the mitochondria and is lethal when knocked out in mice.(75) Like HspA5, HspA9 is involved in protein localization. HspA9 itself is translocated into the mitochondrial matrix through the activity of translocases found in both the inner and outer membranes of the mitochondria. HspA9 is not inducible by heat stress and functions with the mitochondrial chaperonin (multimeric, barrel-shaped chaperone) mtHsp60 and cofactors to form the complete chaperone system of the mitochondria. HspA9 levels are inducible by glucose and generally correlate with muscle activity and mitochondrial respiration. HspA9, like many other mitochondrial proteins, is highly homologous to a bacterial protein, DnaK, and is the only human Hsp70 that is more similar to DnaK than to HspA1A.(76)

    6. Hsp70s and Disease

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Because of their roles as general regulators of proteostasis and their diverse cellular functions, Hsp70s are widely implicated in diseases including cancer, infection, and neurodegenerative disease. A significant challenge to studying these proteins in a pathologic context is a lack of tools for studying specific isoforms. In general, commercial antibodies are not validated for off-target reactivity with similarly sized proteins, and it is quite possible that many reported âHsp70â activities can be traced to some subgroup of isoforms. It can be particularly challenging to differentiate HspA1A, HspA1B, HspA1L, and HspA2. As a result, the following section will summarize relevant literature regarding Hsp70s in disease with a limited regard to the roles of specific isoforms, except where possible.

    6.1. Hsp70 in Cancer

    The first implication of an Hsp70 protein in cancer dates to 1987, when it was first shown that HspA8 interacts with p53.(77) In addition, this is the same year that HspA9 and HspA5 (Grp75 and Grp78, respectively), which had previously been implicated in cancer, were first classified as Hsp70 proteins.(77) Hsp70s are implicated in all the ânext-generationâ hallmarks of cancer.(78,79) Many of these effects of cancer are driven by dysregulation of the tumor suppressor p53. p53 itself has been implicated in all the hallmarks of cancer, particularly genome instability and cellular immortality.(80) HspA9 directly binds to and inactivates p53 leading to an increased proteasomal degradation. HspA1A/A1B stabilizes HDM1, a p53-inhibiting protein, leading to a blockage of p53.(76) HspA8 interacts with and stabilizes inactive p53 mutants. Generally, these mutations would cause a destabilization of p53, which would lead to the death of cells expressing these mutants. However, an HspA8 overexpression allows these mutants to maintain just enough function to keep these cells alive. Despite surviving, the cells harboring these mutants have relatively destabilized genomes and therefore undergo oncogenic transformation.(77,81)

    6.1.a. Hsp70 in Programed Death Suppression

    Hsp70 isoforms are potent suppressors of apoptosis through their action in the inhibition of apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1),(82) C-Jun terminal kinase (JNK),(82â85) BCL-2 associated X apoptosis regulator (BAX),(86) apoptosis protease activating factor 1 (APAF-1),(87â89) and apoptosis inducing factor (AIF).(86,87,90) Hsp70 competes with each of these apoptotic proteins for their appropriate downstream binding partner. As a result, Hsp70 overexpression takes these proteins away from their signaling pathway, resulting in a decrease in the apoptotic signal. Upstream of these proteins, HspA1A/B and HspA8 can degrade tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNFÎ±) in a CHIP-dependent manner further suppressing apoptosis.(82,84) In addition, HspA1A/B is known to chaperone an inhibitor of apoptosis protein, x-linked inhibitor of apoptosis protein (XIAP).(91)
    From the perspective of autophagy, HspA8 overexpression inhibits macro autophagy through the promotion of chaperone-mediated autophagy (CMA) as an alternative.(92) HspA5 in the ER can alleviate ER stress that would otherwise lead to ERAD and apoptosis.(93) HspA9 is a key regulator of the tumor suppressor p53 and is commonly overexpressed in cancer. Although a depletion of HspA9 leads to p53-dependent apoptosis, it has not been shown that HspA9 overexpression leads to apoptosis resistance.(94) It is clear that Hsp70 isoforms play some role in programmed cell death evasion through either the CHIP-proteasome axis (cytoplasmic Hsp70s) or through binding such as for HspA5, HspA9, and HspA8.

    6.1.b. Hsp70 and Evasion of the Immune System

    To survive within the patient, cancer must be able to avoid targeted killing by immune cells. HspA1A and HspA1B are known to be expressed on the surface of cancer cells and in the extracellular microenvironment in tumors.(54) In general, these Hsp70s play a role in inducing an immune response through CD8+ T cells and natural killer (NK) cells. The activation of NK cells is dependent on the presence of interleukin (IL)-2 or IL-5 cytokines.(95â99) A long-term exposure to extracellular Hsp70s can desensitize cancer to immune responses and promote long-term survival and tumor growth.(100) Hsp70 has also been hypothesized to be useful as an adjuvant for an immune therapy in cancer. In 2015 a phase II clinical trial was launched investigating the effect of treating lung carcinoma patients with NK cells exogenously activated by Hsp70 and IL-2.(99) This trial did not show significantly increased survival, but the treatment was well-tolerated by patients.(101)

    6.1.c. Hsp70 and Evasion of Cellular Senescence

    Under basal conditions in cancer Hsp70 can suppress p53 and Cdc2 preventing the induction of oncogene-induced senescence programs.(102) In addition, it has been shown that a depletion of Hsp70 in Her2-expressing nonmalignant mammary epithelial cells (MCF10A) led to cellular senescence by an upregulation of p21 and a depletion of survivin.(103) Interestingly, in a second Her2 positive cell line (SK-BR-3) it was shown that p21 senescence activation was dependent on p53, while survivin activation was p53-independent.(103) It has also been shown that a blockage of heat-shock factor 1 inhibits cancer cell senescence, further supporting the hypothesis that Hsp70 plays a key role in this process.(104) However, more recent studies have shown that HSF-1 blocks senescence in a p53-independent mechanism convoluting the molecular mechanism behind these processes.(105)

    6.1.d. Hsp70 and Replicative Immortality

    In addition to its role in the inactivation of p53, Hsp70 can stabilize an oncogenic mutation of aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase-interacting multifunctional protein 2 (AIMP2) lacking exon 2 (AIMP2-DX2). AIMP2 is a tumor suppressor, but AIMP2-DX2 is associated with an aggressive tumor phenotype and resistance to chemotherapy.(106,107) Hsp70 plays a crucial role in preventing the ubiquitination of AIMP2-DX2.(106)

    6.1.e. Hsp70 in Angiogenesis

    One of the master regulators of angiogenesis in cells is hypoxia-inducible factor 1 (HIF-1). HIF-1 is a heterodimeric transcription factor composed of Î± and Î² subunits that is overexpressed under hypoxic conditions, such as in a tumor, and regulates a number of pro-survival and pro-angiogenic proteins.(108â110) HIF-1Î± is stabilized by Hsp70 in cancer cells, and a depletion of Hsp70 results in a loss of HIF-1 activity.(111) In an independent mechanism, there is evidence that Hsp70 stabilizes endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS), which can promote angiogenesis though interleukin-5 activity.(112)

    6.1.f. Hsp70 in Metastasis

    The role of Hsp70 in metastasis is more complicated than its role in the other hallmarks of cancer. On the surface, evidence from animal models shows that Hsp70 is associated with metastasis to the lymph nodes.(113) In addition, an inhibition of Hsp70 can reduce the aggressiveness of metastasis in breast, cervical, and bladder cancers.(114) Hsp70 helps promote the survival of cancer cells that have been detached from the extracellular matrix through the stabilization of protein kinase B (AKT) and follicle adhesion kinase (FAK).(115â117) Hsp70 peptide complexes isolated from patients with hepatocellular carcinoma induce endothelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in Huh-7 cells through modulation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) p38 pathway.(118)
    Hsp70 has also been shown to act as an inhibitor of metastasis under other circumstances. For instance, the knockdown of Hsp70 in macrophages, HeLa, A549, and MCF7 cancer cells promotes EMT phenotypes.(119,120) This has been shown to be caused by a destabilization of E-cadherin-catenin complexes allowing migration to occur.(119) Hsp70 overexpression can block the phosphorylation of Smad3 and 4, which is an essential step in high glucose-induced EMT.(121) Overall, Hsp70 appears to both induce and block metastasis, and further investigation at the patient level is necessary to further illuminate this subject.

    6.1.g. More General Observations of Hsp70s in Cancer

    As a result of Hsp70s effect on cancer survival, it is common for cancers to be âaddictedâ to Hsp70. It has even been reported that âthe vast majority of tumors overexpress Hsp70â(55,122) and that Hsp70 overexpression in cancer is associated with a poor prognosis.(123â127) More recently, groups have focused on the role or pattern of specific isoforms in cancer. One of the most comprehensive evaluations investigated the levels of all six cytoplasmic Hsp70 isoforms (A1A, A1B, A1L, A2, A6, and A8) in six cancerous and three noncancerous cells lines.(128) From this study, it was shown that each type of cancer (breast, cervical, prostate, liver, and colon) has a unique pattern of Hsp70 overexpression. A more recent publication shows that HspA1A/B and HspA8 affect each otherâs expression (knockdown of one induces the other) and that MCF7 breast cancer cells are only sensitive to siRNAs targeting both Hsp70 isoforms as opposed to A1A/B or A8 alone.(52,129) The human protein atlas is a database with proteome- and transcriptome-wide expression levels from 80â¯000 patients across 17 cancer types. On average, healthy tissue normalized cancer immunohistochemistry (IHC) shows an overexpression of all Hsp70 isoforms at the protein and mRNA level. However, each sample has a unique and varied pattern of Hsp70 overexpression.(55) While this data set is extensive, the antibodies used for IHC are only validated to recognize their specific Hsp70 and not necessarily validated to not recognize other Hsp70s. Therefore, while these data are promising with regard to patterns of Hsp70 overexpression more focused studies are needed to validate the role of specific Hsp70 isoforms in different types of cancers.

    6.1.h. Note on Hsp70 and Destabilizing Mutations

    A particularly interesting way Hsp70 is likely tied to cancer is through its role as a general stabilizer of mutations.(130) In the context of health, mutations are generally thought of as undesirable given their propensity to cause diseases. In fact, much of drug development centers around modulating the function of mutant proteins to return homeostasis. However, the accumulation and retention of mutations is essential for evolutionary progress. As such a highly conserved protein family throughout biology, Hsp70s have a unique role among chaperones of stabilizing and preserving mutations.(130) This is, perhaps, an explanation as to why the evolution of Hsp70 progressed through gene duplication (resulting in multiple isoforms with distinct functions) as opposed to organisms sticking with one Hsp70 isoform and tuning its activity to what is needed most.(33) This role in mutation and evolution has interesting implications in the temporal role of Hsp70 in cancer. While further experimentation is necessary, emerging data suggest that Hsp70 is necessary at high levels, particularly early in cancer development.(122) If this proves to be true, Hsp70 levels may be an effective biomarker for early cancer diagnosis.

    6.1.i. The Epichaperome in Cancer

    In general, the chaperome consists of the heat-shock proteins (HSP90, HSP70, HSP60, HSP40, prefoldin, small HSPs), tetratricopeptide repeat (TPR)-domain-containing proteins, and organellar-specific chaperones of the ER and mitochondria. While all these classes of proteins have been studied extensively, studies of the whole chaperome remained sparse until recently. In 2014, a group of researchers found a subset of the chaperone that was associated with neurodegenerative disease and aging. In addition, the knockdown of these proteins in cellular and fly models of Huntingtonâs disease increased disease phenotypes. In an interaction map of the entire proteome, it was found that this subset of chaperones clustered together.(131) A more recent study profiled the entire chaperome interactome in yeast and discovered a highly interconnected group of chaperones. In many ways, this experimental approach validated the previous findings that chaperones form distinct clusters. Another important observation from this publication was the identification of the so-called ânaturally joinedâ (NAJ) super complex. This consisted of a number of Hsp70, CCT, Hsp90, AAA+, small heat-shock proteins, and JDP proteins that function together to maintain protein homeostasis.(132) In the context of cancer, the Chiosis group published a report revealing changes in the chaperone interactome upon myc overexpression.(133) They showed that, upon a malignant transformation, the chaperone interactome is rewired and a subset of the chaperome assembles a stable complex that promotes survival.(133) This stable complex is nucleated by Hsp90 and HspA8 and is now referred to as the epichaperome. There was no evidence other Hsp70 isoforms participated in the formation of the epichaperome, but as discussed above, it can be challenging to separate Hsp70 isoforms using antibodies or proteomics due to their high homology. The formation of the epichaperome appears to be binary, and in cells that have an assembled epichaperome, it is essential for survival. The characterization of 95 immortalized and 40 primary cell lines revealed that â¼70% expressed the epichaperome. Overall, the observation of the epichaperome has the potential to shift the paradigm of how chaperones are studied. The epichaperome also represents an interesting drug target, since it only exists in a disease state. While Rodina et al. showed that Hsp90 levels are similar between cancer and primary cell lines, epichaperome levels are hugely different. Therefore, a drug targeting epichaperome-associated Hsp90 could, hypothetically, have a much wider therapeutic window than a traditional Hsp90 inhibitor. Epichaperome-associated Hsp90 is selectively targeted by PU-H71, which is currently in clinical trials for both cancer diagnosis and cancer treatment.(134â136) It is also hypothetically possible to target other components of the epichaperome, but it is unclear if this would have a therapeutic effect greater than that of PU-H71. Aside from the epichaperome, the chaperone interactome appears more interconnected under stressed conditions. It has been hypothesized that this interconnectivity reduces the functional redundancy of chaperone groups in cells and renders them more susceptible to a subtle modulation.(137â139) Highly selective chemical probes that target nodes (specific proteins in the chaperone networks) or edges (specific interactions) of the chaperone interaction network will prove invaluable for the investigation of not just Hsp70s but the whole chaperone network in disease.

    6.2. Hsp70 in Neurodegeneration

    Neurodegenerative diseases (NDs) are complex diseases with devastating symptoms. From the perspective of pathology NDs are highly varied in both their risk factors and their population of effect. However, from the perspective of Hsp70 many of these diseases are highly similar. In Alzheimerâs disease (AD), Huntingtonâs disease (HD), and Parkinsonâs disease (PD) characteristic proteins unfold and form cytotoxic soluble aggregates that eventually oligomerize to form fibrils.(140) The characteristic proteins (AD: tau, HD: huntingtin protein (HTT), PD: Î±-synuclein) are universally substrates of Hsp90. To prevent these proteins from aggregating, they must be ubiquitylated and degraded by the proteosome. This can be accomplished through the CHIP system (described above), but under normal conditions Hsp90 prevents CHIP from being recruited. One way to accomplish degradation is to inhibit Hsp90. With Hsp90 out of the picture, Hsp70 can interact with the soluble aggregates and recruit the E3 ligase CHIP to the complex. At this point, CHIP will ubiquitylate the problematic protein, and it will be degraded by the proteosome. Similarly, HspA8 can be overexpressed, at which point it will outcompete Hsp90 for the binding of the soluble aggregate and recruit CHIP. This has been shown to be the general mechanism by which tau, HTT, and Î±-synuclein are degraded by the ubiquitin proteasome system (UPS).(141)
    A second major activity of Hsp70 in neurodegenerative diseases is the disaggregase complex formed by HspA8, class B JDPs, and the bulky Hsp110 nucleotide exchange factors. This process has recently been carefully dissected to reveal that HspA8 alone binds to multiple sequences within amyloid aggregates.(142,143) However, class B JDPs bind to âvulnerableâ stretches of these aggregates and can recruit HspA8. In addition, the Hsp110 class of NEFs are too bulky to access these JDP-HspA8 complexes and instead cycle HspA8 off the aggregate if it is not also bound to a JDP. Overall, these cochaperones selectively recruit HspA8 to positions most productive for an oligomer dissociation. The activity of these three chaperones can disaggregate amyloid, tau, Î±-synuclein, and HTT fibrils.(140,144,145) The product of this disaggregation tends to be soluble polymorphic oligomers, which then proceed to seed further aggregates and increase the amyloid burden in vivo.(146)
    In some respects, the above models seem opposed. A high HspA8 activity would promote tau degradation and amyloid disaggregation, which would have unpredictable effects based on the genetic data. However, chemical modulators of HspA8 paint a different picture. By blocking the association of HspA8 with NEFs using JG-48 (discussed below), it has been shown that tau levels in cell models are decreased. This is because the inability of an NEF to cycle ADP for ATP in HspA8 increases the amount of time the tau spends bound to the SBD, increasing the likelihood of HspA8 to recruit CHIP to tau leading to a proteasomal degradation of the protein.(74) The clearance of tau measured in this study is explained with respect to CHIP-dependent degradation, but, considering the recent studies defining the Hsp110 disaggregase, it would be worthwhile to measure the effect of JG-48 on the disaggregase. It would be predicted that JG-48 would also block the Hsp110-HspA8 interaction, inhibiting the disaggregase and slowing the aggregate spread.
    In addition to HspA8âs role in the Hsp90/CHIP axis or the Hsp110/JDP axis, there is emerging evidence that a tau overexpression in the progression of AD causes the formation of an epichaperome. This epichaperome is not identical to that formed in cancer, but it does have the same core components of Hsp90 and HspA8, among others. In cancer, the epichaperome stabilizes Myc and promotes cell survival, but this epichaperome is not able to deal with tau and promotes neuronal cell death. However, PU-H71 disrupts this complex and restores tau clearance in cells and restores cognitive function in a mouse model of AD.(147) The epichaperome again provides a distinct population of chaperones that can be targeted separately from basal chaperone function to minimize potential side effects associated with blocking a protein with the numerous, diverse functions of Hsp90.

    6.3. Hsp70 in Infectious Disease

    Hsp70 isoforms within bacteria (referred to as DnaK) are essential for bacterial survival within the relatively harsh environment of their hosts. One of the major responses to infection in mammals is fever, which can cause body temperatures to reach 39 Â°C. At this elevated temperature, DnaK becomes essential to the survival of bacteria on agar plates or in a liquid culture.(148,149) Hsp70 and other chaperones also play key roles in the formation of biofilms (Staphylococcus aureus) or for attachment of bacteria to epithelial surfaces (Helicobacter pylori).(148,150,151) While these phenotypes have not been mechanistically mapped to a protein or group of proteins, it is generally hypothesized that some set of proteins essential for survival or invasion require DnaK for proper folding at elevated temperatures or in stressful environments. Recently, it was shown that the pertussis toxin (PT) produced by Bordetella pertussis, the bacteria that causes whooping cough, hijacks the host chaperome to import the PT enzyme into cells. While not a reasonable strategy for a therapeutic, this is a novel example of bacteria hijacking the host chaperone system.(152)
    Because viruses are replicated within cells using host machinery, chaperones play a significant role in the import, replication, folding, assembly, and translocation of various viruses. This dependence on host chaperones argues that host Hsp70 may be a good target for preventing a variety of viral infections. Flaviviruses including zika virus (ZIKV) are among the most well-studied species with respect to Hsp70 intervention. The initial observation that Hsp70 was a target in ZIKV infection stemmed from the observation that Hsp70 copurified with viral particles from infected cells.(153) Further studies showed that a genetic and chemical inhibition of Hsp70 reduced the viral replication in vitro.(153â155) It was then shown that an addition of recombinant Hsp70 to the virus upon infection blocked viral uptake, indicating that Hsp70 is essential for an initial import of the virus. In addition, the inhibition of Hsp70 reduced viral mRNA indicating that Hsp70 is also involved in ZIKV replication.(154) Isoform-specific knockdowns of Hsp70s then revealed that HspA8 is the major effector of ZIKV replication.(155) HspA8 interaction was then mapped to the capsid protein, and treatment with an allosteric Hsp70 inhibitor resulted in a proteosome-dependent degradation of the capsid protein. This same allosteric inhibitor was then shown to be efficacious in a mouse model of ZIKV infection. However, a further study of a compound that targeted Hsp70 ATPase activity showed decreased infection, but not increased survival, in a mouse model of ZIKV.(156) These studies in ZIKV provide a roadmap for how Hsp70s can be validated as targets in a viral infection. Hsp70 has been reported as essential in several other viruses including Enterovirus, EpsteinâBarr, hepatitis B, ectromelia, beet black scorch, rotavirus, human immunodeficiency, polyomavirus, and respiratory syncytial viruses.(157â168) While Hsp70s target different points in the replication of each of these viruses, the general rationale for targeting them is the same as for ZIKV. A decided advantage in targeting host proteins as opposed to viral proteins is the propensity for an evolved resistance. In an infectious disease, the organism being targeted grows rapidly and can readily evolve to be unaffected by a compound targeting them. However, repeated infections at a dose below complete lethality showed no developed resistance to Hsp70 inhibition in ZIKV.(155)

    7. Chemical Modulation of Hsp70s

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Because of the implications of Hsp70 in diseases as outlined above, much work has gone into the development of Hsp70 inhibitors over the last 30 years. However, for several reasons, this has proven to be challenging. Because of its low catalysis rate, high affinity for ATP, and even higher affinity for ADP the enzymatic activity of Hsp70 is difficult to measure and more difficult to inhibit. Numerous efforts to target ATP binding and hydrolysis have been reported, with little success.(169) This resulted in the utilization of assays less biased to a specific activity or binding site such as luciferase refolding assays or direct binding assays. In fact, some of the most potent Hsp70 inhibitors have come out of phenotypic anticancer screens with pulldowns later revealing Hsp70 to be the target of the molecule. Currently, only â¼15 inhibitors have been identified through various means, and these molecules can be placed into six groups based on the binding site on Hsp70 (Table 2 and Figure 5). There are six well-defined pockets on these proteins that have been exploited to different extents (Figure 5).(170) The highest-quality Hsp70 inhibitors (Figure 6) have well-characterized binding mechanisms and cellular modes of action (Class 1 Table 2). However, note that many reported Hsp70 inhibitors (Class 2 Table 2) have been found in phenotypic screens, have poorly defined mechanisms of action, and have no in vitro evidence of direct binding or biochemical inhibition (Figure 6). In addition, a second subset of Hsp70 inhibitors (Class 3 Table 2) have very low biochemical potency and pan-assay inhibitory (PAINS) characteristics (Figure 6).(171,172) This is not to say that class 2 or 3 compounds are unimportant or should be completely disregarded, but further testing and chemical optimization should be done on these scaffolds before they are considered of the same quality as class 1 inhibitors. Currently, there are six well-characterized binding sites on Hsp70s (Figure 5). Four of these sites are in the nucleotide binding domain, and two are in the substrate binding domain. In the following section, several carefully characterized compounds are discussed as representative binders at each of the six specific sites.
    Table 2. Published Hsp70 Inhibitors
    namebiologic activitytargeted Hsp70aclassbinding siterefs
    Mkt-077Induces apoptosis in cancer cells and xenograftsHspA8, A9b13c(173,174,179)
    YM-08BBB penetrant, reduces tau levels in cells, toxic to cancer cellsHspA8, A9b13c(175)
    JG-48reduces tau levels in cells, toxic to cancer cellsHspA8, A9b13c(74)
    HS-72Inhibits proliferation of various cancer cell linesHspA1A/B23(51)
    Hsp70â36Toxic to a panel of cancer and noncancer cellsunknown22(180)
    MAL3â101Activity against Merkel cell carcinoma in cells and in vivounknown16(181,182)
    OridoninN/Aunknown21(183,184)
    YK5Destabilizes Her2 and leads to apoptosis in cancer cellsHspA1A/B, A811c(170)
    HA-15Induces UPR and kills BRAF mutant melanomasHspA51N/A(185)
    PESPrevents myc-induced lymphoma in miceHspA1A/B14c(186,187)
    NovolactoneDestabilizes HER2 and EGFR in cancer cellsHspA1A/B, A5, A814c(188)
    9-amino acridiziniumBlocks clostridium toxin at 100Â Î¼MHspA835(189)
    Methylene BlueReduces tau levelsHspA1A3Other(190)

    HexachloropheneInduces apoptosis and blocks autophagy in melanoma cell linesHspA535(194)
    a

    Reported specificities but not necessarily validated across all Hsp70s.

    b

    Indicates Hsp70 targeting that is selective in cells.

    c

    Indicates structural evidence of binding site. N/A indicates Not Applicable.

    7.1. MKT-077, YM-08, and the JG Series

    MKT-077 was identified in 1999 and shown to have potent anticancer activity.(173) To characterize its mechanism of action, MKT-077 was covalently linked to agarose resin. A pull down with this probe from cancer cells revealed that the compound bound to HspA9. Further biochemical characterization revealed that MKT-077 binds to HspA9 and HspA8 in vitro and inhibits their association with JDP cofactors. It is likely that the selectivity of MKT-077 in cells for HspA9 is driven by the cation found on the pyridine ring. On the basis of favorable activity in mouse xenograft models, a phase 1 clinical trial was launched investigating the MKT-077 efficacy in solid tumors.(173,174) Unfortunately, the trial failed due to the poor absorption and distribution of MKT-077 as well as a significant renal toxicity. Since the failure of MKT-077, a new series of close derivatives has resulted in the compound YM-08, which targets HspA8 (due to a lack of mitochondrial penetration), penetrates the blood brain barrier, and reduces tau levels in vivo.(175) While a promising improvement for this scaffold, the pharmacodynamic properties of YM-08 need to be optimized (10 Î¼M activity in cell-based tau and cancer assays) before it can be considered clinically viable. Another series of compounds related to YM-08 are the JG series of compounds. The JG compounds (such as JG-48; Table 2) have been shown to increase the affinity of HspA8 for tau, resulting in the increased clearance of tau in cell models of tauopathies.(74,176) The most recent advances in the JG series led to JG2â38.(177) Like JG-48 and YM08 this compound is uncharged and therefore should be active against cytoplasmic Hsp70s and not mitochondrial Hsp70s. JG2â38 is approximately sevenfold more potent than JG-48 against a variety of cancer cell lines. This compound binds to site 3 on HspA1A by burying of the 2,3-dihydro-benzothiazole into a pocket defined by R72, K71, T13, F150, P147, and T204. The aniline and pyridine rings rest on hydrophobic surfaces, and the nitrogen atom in the pyridine ring is relatively solvent-exposed (Figure 7).
    Overall, this pocket is very deep and narrow, and there are no obvious modifications to make to JG2â38 to increase its binding affinity. However, Hsp70 is very flexible, so it is possible that further modifications to the JG scaffold could increase the binding affinity in surprising ways. To this end, it may be beneficial to solve a structure of JG2â38 bound to site 3 to get a more precise snapshot of the interacting residues. JG2â38 is currently the most potent published derivative in the JG series, and further cellular, pharmacokinetic, and animal studies will provide insight into the potential clinical translation of this scaffold.

    7.2. VER 155008

    VER 155008 is a derivative of ATP that was discovered to inhibit HspA1A/B in a fluorescence polarization assay using fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC)-ATP as a tracer.(191) It is rather impressive that this compound was found, given that the affinity of Hsp70 for ATP is extremely high. This compound is the most well-characterized example of an ATP-competitive Hsp70 inhibitor. Unfortunately, further isothermal titration calorimetry experiments revealed that this compound binds to HspA8 and HspA5 in addition to HspA1A.(195) Despite this lack of isoform specificity, this compound displays potent toxicity against cancer cells.(52) The binding site of VER 155008 is highly charged, as expected in an ATP binding site (Figure 8). This compound forms hydrogen bonds with several residues as well as waters coordinated in the binding site (Figure 8). These hydrogen bonds are formed by the adenosine and pyrrole rings within VER 155008. The more hydrophobic benzyl rings are oriented against hydrophobic surfaces within the pocket (Figure 8). VER 155008 is highly similar to an adenosine nucleoside; therefore, it is unlikely that Hsp70s are the only proteins targeted by this scaffold.
    Recent medicinal chemistry on this scaffold has centered around making the molecule irreversible by replacing the benzyl nitrile group off the pyrrole with an electrophile with the goal of reaching Cys17 (Figure 8). In a surprise to the authors, the compound did become irreversible, but instead of cysteine the new compound ended up targeting Lys56 (Figure 8).(196) Iterative optimization of the scaffold and covalent warhead led to TCI-18 (Figure 6), which is 100 times more potent than the initial covalent lead. As an irreversible inhibitor, this new compound may prove more useful than VER 155008, since it will not be affected as much by the high cellular levels of ATP.(197) However, no side-by-side comparison of the molecules in cellular or biochemical assays has been undertaken yet. In addition, it is unlikely that the TCI-18 will be any more selective within the Hsp70 family than VER 155008, as the targeted lysine is conserved within the canonical Hsp70s.

    7.3. Phenyl-ethyl-sulfonamide

    Phenyl-ethyl-sulfonamide (PES or pifithrin-Î¼) has been a controversial compound, and as a result it is well-characterized.(186,187) Its low molecular weight and primary sulfonamide make it a prime candidate for PAINS activity.(52) This suspicion is amplified by the fact that this compound was originally identified in a phenotypic assay, and pull down revealed it targeted HspA1A/B. Surprisingly, PES pulls down HspA1A/B and not HspA8 or HspA5 from BX-U2OS (osteosarcoma) and A875 (melanoma) cells. Additionally, it was shown that PES decreased cancer cell viability in vitro and Myc induced Lymphomagenesis in mice.(187) On the basis of the structure of this compound and a lack of biochemical evidence of inhibition, the consensus in the field was that PES affected multiple pathways in cells and that binding to Hsp70 may not be the only reason for the anticancer properties of the compounds. However, in 2014 a derivate of PES containing a triphenylphosphine cation was crystallized bound to DnaK. Further analysis showed this compound was able to inhibit substrate peptide binding to HspA1A in vitro and shown to bind to HspA1A with a KD of 4 Î¼M by isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC).(186) Together, these results validated site 4 as a position on Hsp70 that can be targeted forb the development of selective inhibitors. In 2020, a medicinal chemistry campaign was conducted to identify more potent derivates containing the triphenylphosphine cation. The most potent compound was shown to be 20 times more potent in an ATPase assay (AP-4â139B, Figure 6). In addition, this compound inhibited tumor growth in an HT 29 xenograft model and blocked invasion and metastasis of MC38 cells in Matrigel and tail vein metastasis assays. It was then shown that AP-4â139B causes mitochondrial dysfunction in cells and creates a danger-associated molecular pattern, recruiting immunogenic cells to the tumor.(198) In vitro selectivity of PES or its derivatives has not been validated beyond showing it binds to DnaK and HspA1A/B. On the basis of sequence homology, if the triphenylphosphine-containing compounds bind to HspA1A/B and DnaK, it will likely interact with all human Hsp70 isoforms, but this needs further investigation. Structural information regarding the binding of AP-4â139B is absent; this class of compounds are potent (138 nM) binders of HspA1A and efficacious in various models of cancer.

    7.4. Novolactone

    Shortly after the publication of the binding site of PES, a group from Novartis published the discovery of the natural product novolactone as an Hsp70 inhibitor.(188) Novolactone is less selective than PES, as it binds covalently to E444 in site 4 of HspA1A/B (Figure 9). This Glu residue is conserved in all canonical Hsp70s other than HspA9. Therefore, it is unlikely that novolactone would display selectivity within the Hsp70 family. Novolactone lacks nitrogen atoms and has few potential hydrogen-bond donors and acceptors. This makes it an ideal compound for interacting with the relatively hydrophobic pocket that is site 4 (Figure 9).
    Like PES, novolactone shows potent anticancer activity. However, investigation into the mechanism of action showed an HspA1A/B induction after a treatment with novolactone. This indicates that novolactone may activate HSF1, which is potentially an undesirable effect, as the induction of HSF1 is thought to have played a role in the clinical failure of Hsp90 inhibitors. It is unclear why novolactone and PES derivatives would have different effects on Hsp70 expression, particularly given that they interact in the same site with similar affinities. One hypothesis is that the irreversible nature of novolactone contributes to this signaling, but a careful investigation into this phenomenon has yet to be conducted. Novolactone selectivity in cells was not carefully investigated; induction of Hsp70 could be caused by an off-target interaction.

    7.5. YK5

    Typically, Cys267 in Hsp70 is buried within an Î±-helix, but computational modeling of HspA1A revealed a possible pose where Cys267 is present in a previously undescribed pocket (site 1, Figure 5). By designing an electrophilic ligand to target this cysteine, YK5 was created. YK5 binds to HspA1A/B and HspA8 as validated through pull downs.(170) It is likely this compound binds to all Hsp70s other than HspA5 and HspA9, but this has not been directly measured. YK5 achieves covalent modification at cysteine through an acrylamide group (Figure 10).
    A structure of YK5 bound to Hsp70 has yet to be reported, but the docking shown in Figure 10 agrees with the published model.(170) However, as Cys257 is typically buried in Hsp70 crystal and NMR structures, the model in Figure 10 does not account for the covalent interaction between YK5 and Cys267. The YK5 binding site is a long and shallow groove that is near several basic residues (Figure 10). YK5 contains eight nitrogen atoms, and these participate in several polar contacts including a hydrogen bond with H89 (Figure 10).
    YK5 was shown to inhibit Hsp70 ATPase function and luciferase refolding in vitro. In addition, YK5 initiates the degradation of HER2 in SKBr3 breast cancer cells and blocks growth, both at a concentration of â¼800 nM. Unlike novolactone, YK5 does not induce a heat-shock response upon treatment and thus could be a more viable clinical lead.

    7.6. HA-15

    HA-15 was discovered in 2016 in a screen for compounds that induce UPR in the ER.(185) After the synthesis of a biotinylated probe and pull-down, HA-15 was revealed to bind to HspA5 and localize to the ER in cells. Additionally, this compound weakly inhibits the ATPase activity of HspA5 in vitro. While selectivity has not yet been validated in vitro, the pull-down revealed HspA5 and no other Hsp70 isoforms bound to HA-15. The initial report of HA-15 did not report on the binding site, but direct biding to HspA5 was measured by differential scanning calorimetry and ITC. Since HA15 is the only reported completely selective Hsp70 inhibitor, it is important for future work to focus on the binding mechanism of this compound with HspA5. In addition, an in vitro characterization of HA-15 isoform specificity would serve as a powerful support to the selectivity observed in the pulldowns. Since HspA5 is found in the ER and is a central regulator of the UPR, it is possible that a compound would induce UPR upon inhibition of HspA5. HA-15 inhibits apoptosis and induces autophagy (both a consequence of UPR induction) in melanoma cells and prevents the proliferation of melanoma in a mouse xenograft model.(185) HA-15 is equally effective in v-raf murine sarcoma viral oncogene homologue B1 (BRAF)-resistant melanoma cells, which are resistant to treatment. Therefore, HA-15 serves as a validation for targeting HspA5 as an anticancer therapeutic; however, more work is needed to define the HspA5-dependent mechanism.

    7.7. Mal3â101 and the Dihydropyridines

    In 2004, a medicinal chemistry campaign was conducted by the Brodsky group to combine the effects of NSC-630668-R/1, a known blocker of the Hsp70 and JDP interaction, and 15-deoxyspergualin (DSG), a potent activator of Hsp70 hydrolysis. The result of this undertaking was a series of structurally related molecules that bind to and directly modulate the allosteric network of Hsp70. Mal3â101 was revealed as the best inhibitor from this work, but other molecules activate Hsp70 ATPase activity in a similar manner to JDP. Mal3â101 prevents a JDP-dependent stimulation of Hsp70s ATPase activity but not its basal activity.(182) Further modulation of molecules targeting this pocket resulted in compound 115â7c, which acts as a functional activator of the Hsp70-JDP interaction. In a biologic context, 115â7c can rescue Hsp70 dysfunction in yeast models of polyglutamate disease. In addition, further modification of the scaffold led to 116â9e, which binds to the same site at 115â7c but blocks JDP-stimulated ATPase activity more potently than Mal3â101. 115â7c was shown by NMR to bind to site 6 (Figure 11).(199) This binding site is long, shallow, and hydrophobic. In addition, 115â7c is a very flexible ligand, and while it does fit in the pocket, it is quite tangled. This would indicate that further optimization could be done to reduce the degrees of freedom in a molecule targeting this site allowing higher affinity binding. Although there are NMR data indicating the residues that 115â7c interacts with, a structural study could provide information about the exact nature of the site 6 binding pocket.
    In cells, Mal3â101 induces UPR and leads to apoptotic cell death. Interestingly, cancer cells can become resistant to these molecules by inducing their basal levels of autophagy through ATF4 signaling and induced ERAD. Overall, these molecules suffer from a lack of potency, but given the importance of JDPs to the function of Hsp70s this scaffold is worth pursuing.(200)

    7.8. NRLLLTG

    The final binding site on Hsp70 that has been validated is site 5, the peptide substrate binding pocket. This binding site exists as a long groove across the base of the SBD (Figure 12). Currently, the only ligand that has been directly shown to bind to this site is the minimal substrate peptide NRLLLTG. As described above, this peptide was first discovered in a phage display screen looking for DnaK interactors and has since been used to solve several Hsp70 SBD structures.
    The NRLLLTG peptide binds through a complex network involving myriad interactions with the peptide backbone. As this site is designed to interact promiscuously with hydrophobic and aggregation-prone sequences, it stands to reason that much of the binding would be defined by the peptide backbone and not the R-groups. There is also a deep and small hydrophobic pocket in which one of the leucine residues is buried, explaining the preference for hydrophobic residues in the middle of interacting peptides (Figures 3 and 12). This binding site has yet to be seriously targeted with small molecules, as it is small and hydrophobic. However, it is hypothesized that hexachlorophene and 9-amino acridizinium target this site, but direct evidence for these compounds binding is lacking. Another potential challenge associated with this binding is that of occupancy. Because Hsp70s are typically bound to a client protein it can be kinetically challenging to outcompete client proteins with peptides or small molecules. However, there is some evidence of functional variance at this site that suggests this could be a site to target for the development of isoform-selective modulators.

    7.9. Challenges of Selective Hsp70 Inhibition

    Despite the wide array of available Hsp70 inhibitors, none have been conclusively shown to be selective. The success of YK5 indicates in silico design can be used to successfully target a specific site on Hsp70s. Another strategy that has been utilized in the pursuit of selectivity has been the localization of compounds to specific organelles. MKT-077 shows some cellular selectivity for HspA9 due to a dispersed cation that directs the compound into the mitochondria.(173,175,176,179) Similarly, we have reported that the natural product derived compound ritterostatin GN1N shows selectivity for HspA5 in cells despite it not binding to HspA5 with a higher affinity than the cytosolic Hsp70s.(193) A more traditional strategy to develop selective compounds involves targeting sites on Hsp70 that are less conserved among isoforms. However, there are no obvious variances between the sequences of the canonical Hsp70 isoforms in the predefined pockets. However, there is a cysteine that is found only in HspA5 located in site 4 (Cys420) (Figure 13).
    Aside from a few occasionally unconserved residues there are few, if any, pockets of low conservation in the canonical Hsp70 family (Figure 4B). This makes the challenge of developing a selective inhibitor a daunting one. However, as previously discussed, there are functional differences between the Hsp70s. In general, Hsp70s interact with unique panels of NEFs and JDPs; therefore, it may be possible to selectively target sites near NEF and JDP association areas.(201,202) The JG series represents an interesting scaffold from this perspective, as they bind near the NEF site (Figure 5). However, their specific binding site is almost completely conserved.(74) Similarly, the site of JDP binding is associated with site 6 (Figure 5), which is targeted by Mal3â101 and the dihydropyridines. It would be interesting to evaluate the selectivity of these compounds and see if they follow any of the functional differences present between the Hsp70 isoforms. The location of substrate binding, site 4, (Figure 5) is another that could be targeted for selective inhibitor development. Currently, this site is under-probed, but we recently published that Hsp70 substrate peptide recognition may be less highly conserved between isoforms than would be predicted based on sequence homology. We conducted a pilot screen to find competitive inhibitors of peptide binding and were able to show that hexachlorophene was able to selectivity inhibit peptide binding in HspA5 as compared to DnaK.(194) Hexachlorophene has been reported as a PAINS compound in a number of screens, but we believe that its selectivity in our assay may validate our hypothesis that Hsp70-client interactions are not conserved between isoforms. While more work in this area is needed and ongoing, we hypothesize that a characterization of the divergent peptide recognition at this position will reveal a strategy by which each Hsp70 can be selectively targeted in cells and in vivo.

    8. Conclusions and Future Directions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The Hsp70s are complex molecular machines that have a fascinating and byzantine evolutionary history. While the field is mature, numerous questions remain unanswered, such as the mechanism for client protein selectivity and the role of individual isoforms in higher organisms. These two questions are intertwined, and the answers may have a substantial impact on the treatment of various diseases. It would be surprising if the interaction of JDPs was the only factor determining client selectivity given that there are divergent sequences between Hsp70 isoforms and evolution does not typically create unnecessary differences. Another biologic argument for Hsp70s themselves playing a role in client selection is the fact that cancers differently regulate specific Hsp70 isoforms. Although the pattern has not been completely elucidated, it is quite possible that oncogenes may depend on a specific Hsp70 isoform. If these interactions can be defined, there is a chance that Hsp70 inhibitors could serve as powerful tools for treating and diagnosing these cancers. In addition to cancer, positron emission tomography (PET) probes targeting Hsp70 could be useful tools for diagnosing early stage neurodegenerative diseases including Alzheimerâs Disease and Parkinsonâs Disease.
    Currently, numerous Hsp70 inhibitors have been reported, but the major challenge remains isoform selectivity. None of the reported inhibitors have been tested in parallel against the complete panel of Hsp70s. While these potentially promiscuous compounds have shown promising anticancer activity, none have advanced to the clinic. It is unclear if this is due to a lack of specificity within the Hsp70 family, but the development of specific Hsp70 inhibitors will go a long way to validate these proteins as anticancer targets. In light of the discovery of the epichaperome, it is less clear if specificity is necessary in the development of Hsp70-targeting therapeutics. While genetic evidence suggests that the inhibition of multiple Hsp70s is necessary, with strong and selective probes for specific Hsp70 isoforms we can begin to answer questions about the role of specific isoforms in basic biology and cancer. Efforts to identify selective Hsp70 inhibitors have focused on targeting structural differences between the isoforms. Because there are few published structures of Hsp70 substrate binding domains, rationally designed Hsp70 inhibitors target the nucleotide binding domain. While the strategy of rational design has shown some success, phenotypic screens that are agnostic to target have shown equal success. Inhibitors of G-protein coupled receptors tend to be the most selective discovered to date, and they are developed by targeting sites of functional divergence within the receptors. Going forward, a novel strategy for targeting Hsp70s selectivity may involve targeting sites of divergent function between the proteins. We have begun to show an unpredicted variance in the function of the Hsp70 substrate binding domains (unpublished data), which we believe will result in highly selective Hsp70 inhibitors. The toolkit of selective Hsp70 modulators will go a long way toward unraveling Hsp70 biology and combating some of the most debilitating diseases facing society today.

The refolding is fast, and the data can be described as a sequence of two first-order processes, with half times of about 55 and 350 msec,resp.

      7
      Major heat shock gene of Drosophila and the Escherichia coli heat-inducible dnaK gene are homologous
      Bardwell, James C. A.; Craig, Elizabeth A.
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1984), 81 (3), 848-52CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
      The E. coli dnaK gene is homologous to the major heat shock-induced gene in Drosophila (Hsp70). The primary DNA sequence of the entire protein-coding region of the dnaK gene was detd. and compared with that of the Hsp70 gene of Drosophila. The 2 sequences are homologous; the dnaK gene could encode a 69,121-dalton polypeptide that is 48% identical to the hsp70 protein of Drosophila. The homol. between the Hsp70 gene of Drosophila and the E. coli dnaK gene illustrates the remarkable conservation of the heat-shock genes in evolution. In contrast to Drosophila and Saccharomyces cerevisiae, both of which contain multigene families related to the Hsp70 gene, hybridization analyses indicate that E. coli contains only a single Hsp70-related gene, dnaK. Hybridization of the DNA of an archaebacterium Methanosarcina barkeri and the Hsp70 genes of Drosophila, Saccharomyces, and E. coli has been detected, which suggests the existence of Hsp70-related genes in the 3 primary kingdoms : eukaryotes, eubacteria, and archaebacteria.
